RBI/2024-25/83 CO.DPSS.POLC.No.S-708/02-12-004/2024-25 October 11, 2024

All Payment System Participants

Madam / Dear Sir,

## **Facilitating accessibility to digital payment systems for Persons with Disabilities – Guidelines**

A reference is invited to Reserve Bank's [Master Circular on Customer Service in Banks dated](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=9862)  [July 01, 2015,](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=9862) which, among other things, contains instructions for scheduled commercial banks to ensure banking services for Persons with Disabilities. In this context, reference is also invited to ['Accessibility Standards and Guidelines for Banking Sector'](https://financialservices.gov.in/beta/sites/default/files/2024-08/Guidelines-for-Banking-Sector.pdf) as notified by the Ministry of Finance, Government of India on February 02, 2024.

2. All sections of population, including differently abled persons, are increasingly adopting digital payment systems. To promote effective access, payment system participants (PSPs, that is, banks and authorised non-bank payment system providers) are advised to review their payment systems / devices in terms of accessibility to Persons with Disabilities. Based on the review they may carry out the necessary modifications, such that all their payment systems and devices, such as Point-of-Sale machines, can be accessed and used by Persons with Disabilities with ease. In this connection, the Accessibility Standards issued by the Ministry of Finance referred to above may also be adhered to, as applicable, by all PSPs. While selecting potential solutions for the purpose, care should be taken to ensure that the modifications / enhancements do not compromise security aspects of their systems.

3. PSPs shall submit to the Reserve Bank, within one month of the date of issue of this circular, details of their systems / devices that need to be modified, along with a time bound plan of action for achieving the same. The action plan may be sent to the Department of Payment and Settlement Systems, Reserve Bank of India at [dpssfeedback@rbi.org.in](mailto:dpssfeedback@rbi.org.in) along with details of a Nodal Officer who could be contacted, if required, for further queries / clarifications.

4. This directive is issued under Section 18 read with Section 10 (2) of the Payment and Settlement Systems Act, 2007 (Act 51 of 2007).

Yours faithfully,

(Gunveer Singh) Chief General Manager-in-Charge

5. To be eligible for accepting public deposits, the deposit taking HFCs shall invariably obtain minimum investment grade credit rating as specified in para 25 of [Master](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasDirections.aspx?id=12030)  Direction – Non-Banking Financial Company – [Housing Finance Company \(Reserve](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasDirections.aspx?id=12030)  [Bank\) Directions, 2021](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasDirections.aspx?id=12030) at least once a year. In case their credit rating is below the minimum investment grade, such HFCs shall not renew existing deposits or accept fresh deposits thereafter till they obtain an investment grade credit rating.

6. The ceiling on quantum of public deposits held by deposit taking HFCs, which comply with all prudential norms and minimum investment grade credit rating as specified, shall stand reduced from 3 times to 1.5 times of net owned fund. Deposit taking HFCs holding deposits in excess of the revised limit shall not accept fresh public deposits or renew existing deposits till they conform to the revised limit. However, the existing excess deposits will be allowed to run off till maturity.

7. Currently, HFCs are allowed to accept or renew public deposits repayable after a period of twelve months or more but not later than one hundred and twenty months from the date of acceptance or renewal of such deposits. It has been decided that henceforth, the public deposits accepted or renewed by HFCs shall be repayable after a period of twelve months or more but not later than sixty months. Existing deposits with maturities above sixty months shall be repaid as per their existing repayment profile.

qa_pairs.question: What declarations must NBFC-P2P platforms obtain from lenders, and what restrictions apply to promoting P2P lending as an investment?
qa_pairs.answer: NBFC-P2P platforms are required to obtain explicit declarations from lenders confirming they understand the risks associated with lending transactions, acknowledging that the platform does not assure return of principal or payment of interest, and recognizing the potential for complete loss of principal if a borrower defaults. Additionally, P2P platforms must not promote peer-to-peer lending as an investment product offering assured returns or liquidity options.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately describe the required declarations from lenders, including understanding of risks, non-assurance of returns, and potential for loss of principal. The answer should also mention the restrictions on promoting P2P lending as an investment product.

qa_pairs.question: How should fund transfers between participants on a Peer to Peer Lending Platform be conducted?
qa_pairs.answer: NBFC-P2P platforms must use escrow accounts operated by a bank-promoted trustee for fund transfers. There should be two accounts: one for funds received from lenders pending disbursal and another for collections from borrowers. Funds from the lenders' escrow account can only be disbursed to the borrower's bank account after compliance with paragraph 8(3) of the directions is ensured, and repayment funds from borrowers must be transferred from the borrower's account to the borrowers' escrow account and then to the respective lender's bank account. Funds from the 'Lenders' Escrow Account' cannot be used for loan repayment, and funds from the 'Borrowers' Escrow Account' cannot be used for loan disbursement. Additionally, funds in the Escrow Accounts cannot remain there for more than 'T+1' day, where 'T' is the date the funds were received.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately describe the escrow account mechanism for fund transfers, including the roles of the two escrow accounts, the permissible fund flows, and the maximum holding period. It should mention the bank-promoted trustee and the T+1 day limit.

qa_pairs.question: What restrictions apply to NBFC-P2P platforms regarding credit enhancements, guarantees, and cross-selling?
qa_pairs.answer: NBFC-P2P platforms cannot offer or arrange credit enhancements or guarantees and must ensure lenders bear the full risk of loss. They are also prohibited from cross-selling any product except for loan-specific insurance products, and cannot cross-sell insurance products that act as credit enhancements or guarantees.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately describe the restrictions on credit enhancements/guarantees and cross-selling for NBFC-P2P platforms. It should mention the exception for loan-specific insurance and the prohibition of cross-selling insurance as credit enhancement.

qa_pairs.question: What kind of policy should an NBFC-P2P have in place for matching lenders with borrowers, and what characteristics should it embody?
qa_pairs.answer: An NBFC-P2P must have a Board-approved policy that sets out rules for matching or mapping lenders with borrowers in an equitable and non-discriminatory manner.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately state the requirement for a Board-approved policy and its purpose regarding lender-borrower matching, including the terms 'equitable' and 'non-discriminatory'.

qa_pairs.question: What borrower details must an NBFC-P2P disclose to lenders?
qa_pairs.answer: An NBFC-P2P must disclose details about borrowers to lenders, including personal identity (with consent kept on record), the required loan amount, the interest rate sought, and the credit score as determined by the NBFC-P2P.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should include all the specific details that an NBFC-P2P is required to disclose to a lender about a borrower, including the requirement for consent regarding personal identity disclosure.

qa_pairs.question: What portfolio performance metrics must an NBFC-P2P publicly disclose on its website?
qa_pairs.answer: An NBFC-P2P must publicly disclose on its website its portfolio performance, including the share of non-performing assets (NPAs) on a monthly basis, segregated by age. Disclosures should also include all losses borne by lenders on principal, interest, or both.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately describe the required disclosures on an NBFC-P2P's website, including the frequency, types of data, and additional information about losses.

qa_pairs.question: What minimum net worth must a Chartered Accountant certify for a lender investing more than Rs. 10,00,000 across P2P platforms?
qa_pairs.answer: An NBFC-P2P must ensure that lenders producing a certificate from a practicing Chartered Accountant do so to certify a minimum net worth of Rs. 50,00,000, when the amount lent by the lender is more than Rs. 10,00,000 across P2P platforms.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately state the net worth amount to be certified by the Chartered Accountant and the lending amount that triggers the certification requirement. The currency (Rs.) must be included. The amounts must be numerically correct.

qa_pairs.question: What functions are NBFC-P2P platforms prohibited from outsourcing?
qa_pairs.answer: An NBFC-P2P cannot outsource core management functions, including Internal Audit, Strategic and Compliance functions, pricing of services/fees to be charged, and decision-making functions such as determining compliance with KYC norms. However, for NBFC-P2Ps within a group/conglomerate, these functions may be outsourced within the group, subject to compliance with Para 6. While the internal audit function itself is a management process, the internal auditors can be on contract.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately list the core management functions that NBFC-P2Ps cannot outsource, and correctly state the conditions under which outsourcing within a group/conglomerate is permissible. The exception regarding internal auditors being on contract should also be included.

qa_pairs.question: What is the aggregate exposure limit for a lender across all P2P platforms, and under what conditions is a net worth certificate required?
qa_pairs.answer: The aggregate exposure of a lender to all borrowers at any point in time, across all P2P platforms, is capped at Rs. 50,00,000, provided the amount lent is consistent with their net worth. If a lender invests more than Rs. 10,00,000 across P2P platforms, they must provide a certificate from a practicing Chartered Accountant confirming a minimum net worth of Rs. 50,00,000.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately state the exposure limit for lenders across P2P platforms, the condition for this limit, the threshold for requiring a net worth certificate, and the minimum net worth to be certified. All monetary values must be exact and correctly formatted with commas.

qa_pairs.question: Under what conditions can a loan be disbursed on a Peer to Peer Lending Platform?
qa_pairs.answer: Loans should not be disbursed unless both lenders and borrowers have been appropriately matched/mapped according to the board-approved policy, and all involved parties have signed the loan contract.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately state the conditions required before a loan can be disbursed, including matching of lenders and borrowers and the signing of the loan contract. The answer should also mention the board-approved policy.

qa_pairs.question: Who bears the loss of principal or interest in peer-to-peer lending transactions, and how should this be disclosed?
qa_pairs.answer: NBFC-P2P platforms cannot assume any credit risk arising from transactions on their platform, meaning lenders bear the entire loss of principal or interest, and this must be disclosed in the fair practices code.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately state that NBFC-P2Ps cannot assume credit risk, lenders bear the loss, and this must be disclosed. Check for the inclusion of 'credit risk', 'lenders bear the loss', and 'fair practices code'.

qa_pairs.question: What is the maximum time period that funds can remain in the Lenders' and Borrowers' Escrow Accounts on a Peer to Peer Lending Platform?
qa_pairs.answer: The funds transferred into the Lenders' Escrow Account and Borrowers' Escrow Account shall not remain in these Escrow Accounts for a period exceeding 'T+1' day, where 'T' is the date on which the funds are received in these Escrow Accounts.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately state the maximum duration funds can remain in the Lenders' and Borrowers' Escrow Accounts, including the 'T+1' day stipulation and the definition of 'T'.

qa_pairs.question: Who bears the risk of loss of principal or interest in transactions on an NBFC-P2P platform?
qa_pairs.answer: NBFC-P2P platforms cannot assume any credit risk arising from transactions on their platform, either directly or indirectly; the entire loss of principal or interest is to be borne by the lenders.
qa_pairs.evaluation_criteria: The answer should accurately state that NBFC-P2P platforms cannot assume credit risk and that lenders bear the loss. It should also mention that this applies to both principal and interest.

qa_pairs.question: How should NBFC-P2Ps handle fund transfers between lenders and borrowers according to the prescribed Funds Transfer Mechanism?
qa_pairs.answer: NBFC-P2Ps must adopt the Funds Transfer Mechanism described in Annex-I, ensuring funds from lenders' bank accounts are transferred only to the Lenders' Escrow Account and disbursed to the borrower's bank account after compliance with paragraph 8(3). Borrowers must repay loans from their bank account to the Borrowers' Escrow Account, from which funds are transferred to the respective lender's bank account. Funds from the Lenders' Escrow Account cannot be used for loan repayment, and funds from the Borrowers' Escrow Account cannot be used for loan disbursement.

(Vaibhav Chaturvedi) Chief General Manager

## **'Fully Accessible Route' for Investment by Non-residents in Government Securities – Exclusion of new issuances in 14-year and 30-year tenor securities**

A reference is invited to the Fully Accessible Route introduced by the Reserve Bank, *vide* [A.P.](https://rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=11849&Mode=0)  [\(DIR Series\) Circular No. 25 dated March 30, 2020,](https://rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=11849&Mode=0) wherein certain specified categories of Central Government securities were opened fully for non-resident investors without any restrictions, apart from being available to domestic investors as well.

2. The Government Securities that are eligible for investment under the Fully Accessible Route ('specified securities') were notified by the Bank, *vide* [circular no.](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=11850&Mode=0)  [FMRD.FMSD.No.25/14.01.006/2019-20 dated March 30, 2020,](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=11850&Mode=0) [circular no.](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=12354&Mode=0)  [FMRD.FMID.No.04/14.01.006/2022-23 dated July 07, 2022,](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=12354&Mode=0) [circular no. FMRD.FMID.No.](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=12444&Mode=0)  [07/14.01.006/2022-23 dated January 23, 2023](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=12444&Mode=0) and [FMRD.FMID.No.04/14.01.006/2023-24](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_CircularIndexDisplay.aspx?Id=12563)  [dated November 08, 2023.](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_CircularIndexDisplay.aspx?Id=12563)

Consequently, future issuances of Government Securities in these tenors shall not be available for investment under the Fully Accessible Route. Existing stocks of Government Securities in 14-year and 30-year tenors already included as 'specified securities' under the Fully Accessible Route shall, however, continue to be available under the Fully Accessible Route for investments by non-residents in the secondary market.

Dear Sir/ Madam,

## **Guidelines on treatment of Dividend Equalisation Fund (DEF)- Primary (Urban) Co-operative Banks (UCBs)**

Please refer to Master [Circular DOR.CAP.REC.5/09.18.201/2024-25 dated April 01,](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=12654)  [2024](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=12654) on "Prudential Norms on Capital Adequacy - Primary (Urban) Co-operative Banks (UCBs)", [Master Circular DoR.CRE.REC.71/07.10.002/2023-24 dated January](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=12600)  [16, 2024](https://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=12600) on "Exposure Norms and Statutory / Other Restrictions – UCBs", and [circular](https://rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=7426&Mode=0) [UBD.BPD.\(PCB\).Cir.No.4/12.05.001/2012-13 dated July 05, 2012](https://rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=7426&Mode=0) on "Declaration of Dividend by the UCBs".

2. It is observed that some UCBs have created the Dividend Equalisation Fund (DEF) through appropriation of profits, with an intent to utilise these balances to pay dividend in future years, when profits are not sufficient or where the bank has posted a net loss. However, extant guidelines on ["Declaration of Dividends by UCBs" dated July 05, 2012](https://rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=7426&Mode=0) *ibid* prohibit dividend payments from previously accumulated profits or reserves and mandate that dividend can only be paid by the banks from net profit of the current year after making all statutory and other provisions and after adjustment for accumulated losses in full. It is also observed that UCBs have been considering the balances in DEF as part of Tier-II capital.

3. In order to provide a better treatment of these balances for regulatory capital purposes, it has been decided, as a onetime measure, to permit UCBs to transfer the balances in the DEF to general reserves/free reserves. The credit balances in general reserves/free reserves, shall qualify as Tier-I capital as per our Master Circular *ibid.*
